q: Can I take my bike on a tram?
a: No, bicycles are not permitted on trams, but folding bikes are allowed if folded.

q: Do children need a ticket on trams?
a: Children under 5 travel free. Children aged 5–18 need a child Myki or concession ticket.

q: Is Wi-Fi available on trams?
a: No, trams do not have Wi-Fi, but many tram stops in the CBD have free public Wi-Fi nearby.

q: What should I do if I lose my Myki card?
a: If registered, report the lost card online or by phone to block it and transfer the balance to a new card.

q: How do I know if a tram is low-floor accessible?
a: Accessible services are marked in PTV timetables and apps with a wheelchair symbol.

q: Can I eat or drink on trams?
a: Eating hot food is not allowed. Drinking water is fine, but alcohol is prohibited.

q: Are pets allowed on trams?
a: Small animals in secure carriers are allowed. Assistance animals like guide dogs can travel anytime.

q: Do trams accept cash for tickets?
a: No, trams do not sell tickets. You must have a valid Myki card before boarding.

q: How do I check if my tram is delayed?
a: Use the PTV app, website, or Twitter updates for live service information.

q: What is the Free Tram Zone?
a: It covers Melbourne’s CBD and Docklands. Travel is free within this zone and no Myki is required.

q: How do I know which tram stop to get off at?
a: Tram stops are announced and displayed on board. You can also check route maps on PTV apps.

q: Can I top up my Myki on the tram?
a: No, top ups must be done before boarding via Myki machines, 7-Eleven stores, or the PTV app.

q: What happens if my Myki balance is negative?
a: You can still finish your trip, but you must top up before your next journey.

q: How much is the tram fare in Melbourne?
a: A daily fare is capped at $10.60 (full fare) and $5.30 (concession) as of 2025.

q: Do trams operate on public holidays?
a: Yes, trams operate every day, but services may run to a Sunday or public holiday timetable.

q: Where can I find tram route maps?
a: Route maps are available on the PTV website, PTV app, and at major tram stops.

q: Do Melbourne trams have toilets?
a: No, trams do not have toilets. Public toilets are available near many tram stops in the CBD.

q: Are face masks required on trams?
a: As of 2025, masks are not mandatory but recommended if you are unwell.

q: Can international visitors use trams?
a: Yes, anyone can use trams with a Myki card, available at retailers and PTV hubs.

q: What should I do if a Myki reader is not working?
a: Try another reader on the tram. If all are faulty, you won’t be fined.

q: Do trams have air conditioning?
a: Most modern low-floor trams have air conditioning. Older models may not.

q: Can I carry luggage on trams?
a: Yes, but you must keep luggage clear of aisles and doors for safety.

q: How early do trams start running in the morning?
a: Most trams begin around 5am, with earlier services on some routes.

q: Are there express trams in Melbourne?
a: No, all trams stop at every stop along their route.

q: Can I use contactless credit cards instead of Myki?
a: No, Melbourne trams currently only accept Myki cards.

q: Are there penalties for not having a valid Myki?
a: Yes, you may receive a fine of up to $240 if caught without a valid ticket.

q: What do the tram stop numbers mean?
a: Each tram stop has a unique number for easier navigation on maps and apps.

q: Do trams announce the next stop?
a: Yes, stops are announced over speakers and shown on electronic displays.

q: Can I travel with a pram on trams?
a: Yes, prams are allowed, but please use the designated low-floor entrances.

q: How can I plan a tram journey?
a: Use the journey planner on the PTV website or app to find routes and times.

q: Are there discounts for seniors on trams?
a: Yes, seniors receive concession fares with a Seniors Myki card.

q: Can tourists get a special tram pass?
a: Yes, the Myki Explorer pack is available for visitors and includes a preloaded card.

q: Do trams stop if no one presses the button?
a: Yes, trams usually stop at every stop unless marked as 'Stop on request'.

q: Can I eat ice cream or coffee on the tram?
a: Food and drinks are discouraged to keep trams clean. Water is fine.

q: How do I know if a tram is full?
a: You can check crowding levels on the PTV app for some services.

q: Do trams run during major events?
a: Yes, extra services often run for events like AFL games and Moomba Festival.

q: What should I do in an emergency on a tram?
a: Use the emergency intercom to speak to the driver or call 000 if needed.

q: Are there school student passes for trams?
a: Yes, students can apply for a PTV School Student ID card for concession fares.

q: Can I transfer between trams without extra cost?
a: Yes, as long as your Myki has a valid fare, transfers between trams, trains, and buses are free within the time limit.

q: Are tram stops announced in multiple languages?
a: No, announcements are in English only, but PTV apps support multiple languages.
